Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Rational Design of Biomimetic Virus-Trapping Polymers
Award.AbstractNarration: PART 1: NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY<br/><br/>The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a pandemic of profound global impact. Its high infectivity enabled it to spread rapidly across the world. In severe cases, infection with SARS-CoV-2 leads to respiratory failure, septic shock, and failure of vital organs, including the liver and kidneys. In the absence of an effective vaccine or therapeutic agent, reducing the populationâ€™s exposure to the virus is the only viable strategy for preventing infections and overburdening of the health care system. Transmission of SARS-CoV-2 occurs through multiple routes. Prevention of SARS-CoV-2 transmission requires effective and easy-to-use technologies directed against all modes of transmission. Funded by the Biomaterials Program in the Division of Materials Research of the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, and cofunded by the Molecular Biophysics Program in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences of the Biological Sciences Directorate, this Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant supports research into the development of biomimetic polymers that exploit the carbohydrate-binding properties of SARS-CoV-2 for virus immobilization. The developed polymers will be designed to produce virus-immobilizing gels and surfaces for applications in protective formulations and devices as well as functional studies, isolation, and purification of virions in scientific settings. The research serves the national interest by advancing the science of biomimetic materials and developing materials for the improvement of national health. <br/> <br/>PART 2: TECHNICAL SUMMARY<br/><br/>The SARS-CoV-2 virus consists of single-stranded RNA that is enclosed in the nucleocapsid protein. This viral core is surrounded by a lipid membrane with three embedded proteins: the envelope protein, the membrane protein, and the spike (S) protein, which is responsible for binding to host cell receptors and host cell entry. The S protein has recently been shown to bind to the glycosaminoglycan (GAG) heparin. This project will integrate simulation, synthesis, and characterization in a forward- and backward-feeding loop approach to rationally design carbohydrate-conjugated polymers for immobilization of SARS-CoV-2 virions. Computer simulations will focus on defining the preferred GAG structures and topology of the S protein binding regions and will include structure modeling of the S protein, molecular docking of GAG oligosaccharides to the S protein, and molecular dynamics simulation of the co-complexes. Synthesis strategies toward GAG-conjugated polymers will include self-condensing ring-opening polymerization, self-condensing vinyl polymerization, and surface-initiated polymerization. Characterization and quantification of binding to the S-protein will be done by biolayer interferometry, surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy, and quartz crystal microgravimetry with dissipation monitoring.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) grant supported research into the development of biomimetic polymers that exploit the carbohydrate-binding properties of SARS-CoV-2 for virus immobilization. Multi-gram scale syntheses have been developed for key materials precursors, thereby overcoming a common limitation of glycomaterial synthesis, that is, relatively small-scale syntheses that preclude production of large amounts of the target materials. Moreover, modular and hyperbranched polymers have been synthesized both as platforms for surface analysis and as precursors to glycomaterials. These polymers will enable rapid surface functionalization with and analysis of various binding motifs. Additionally, a robust and accurate assay for quantifying Spike ? receptor binding has been developed. The binding assay enables quantification of the relative affinities of any glycosaminoglycan (GAG) for the Spike glycoprotein and enables determination of whether binding of GAGs to the Spike protein inhibits binding to host cell receptor ACE2. A computer model for the 3D structure of the Spike glycoprotein interacting with GAG (heparin) fragments was generated from previously reported data.  The 3D models of GAG ? Spike interactions may be the first to include the N-linked glycans in the Spike structures. The model suggests that GAG-based glycomaterials may be able to interfere with the ability of the virus to infect host cells by blocking the interaction between the protein?s receptor binding domain and the ACE2 receptor. The research served the national interest by advancing the science of biomimetic materials and developing materials for the improvement of national health.
